title: I am a judgement creditor and am preparing a "writ of execution"
question: I plan to deliver this to the local sheriff who will take it to the judgement debtor's bank. I know the bank and the debtor's account number. However the judgement debtor knows I will be doing this soon. What is to keep them from taking all their money out of the account before the sheriff comes and then putting it back in once the writ has been served.
answers:
Other counsel have provided good answers regarding the pitfalls of known attempts to levy assets. I just want to supplement their answers by pointing out you cannot simply fill out a writ of execution and deliver it straight to the county sheriff. You must first submit it to the clerk of court in the court in which the matter was filed along with a check for $25.00 payable to "Clerk of the Court." If the writ is accurate, the clerk will issue it and return it to you in the SASE you provided; it may take weeks for the clerk to issue the writ. Don't forget to file and serve a memo of costs to claim post-judgment costs and interest.

Once you receive the issued writ, send it not necessarily to your "local" sheriff; send it to the county sheriff who presides over the area in which the bank is located. The sheriff probably has a website; look under a category such as "court services" or "service of process." You must write the sheriff a letter containing certain information plus levy instructions; the website might provide a fill-in-the blanks form for levy instructions. The sheriff will charge a $30-35 fee.

The Rutter Group's "Enforcing Judgments and Debts" practice guide is very useful for judgment enforcement procedures.

Good luck!

A judgment debtor is "free" to move funds out of accounts if he thinks that a levy is coming. A collection attorney chasing a judgment debtor may send bank levies to several banks that are considered (based on location, past history, etc) likely.

This kind of conduct is not completely without risk, however, In addition to the problems it creates with the judgment debtor's banking relationships (pointed out above), the Bankruptcy Code makes in possible to successfully object to a chapter 7 discharge if the Debtor is shown to have "transferred, removed, destroyed, mutilated, or concealed" his property to avoid a levy.

Sorry, nothing prevents a judgment debtor from closing a bank account or taking money out of a bank account to avoid a levy.

Your best bet would be to take a judgment debtor's exam.

https://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/judgment-debtor-exams-in-california?ref=kb_serp_title_1

Hiding assets from judgment creditors sometimes feels like a national sport in between Nascar and Hockey. Nothing. but as a practical matter, the bank may involuntarily close their account, and if, through some mechanism I don't understand, they get put on the "bank watch list" no bank will open an account for them. Imagine trying to live a modern life with out a bank account.
